discussion.content: A and B https://developer.cisco.com/learning/tracks/iosxe-programmability/intro-device-level-interfaces/intro-netconf/step/2

Selected Answer: AB
A and B
Its in the book

Selected Answer: AB
A and B are correct.

NETCONF - Operations
<get> = Retrieve running configuration and device state information
<get-config> = Retrieve all or part of specified configuration data store
<edit-config> = Loads all or part of a configuration to the specified data store
<copy-config> = Replace an entire configuration data store with another
<delete-config> = Delete a configuration data store
<commit> = Copy candidate data store to running data store
<lock>/unlock> = Lock or unlock the entire configuration data store system
<close-session> = Graceful termination of NETCONF session
<kill-session> = Forced termination of NETCONF session
https://www.claise.be/netconf-versus-restconf-capabilitity-comparisons-for-data-model-driven-management-2/

questions.question_text: Which two NETCONF operations cover the RESTCONF GET operation? (Choose two.)

choices.D: The playbook backs up the start-up configuration of CISCO_ROUTER_01
choices.A: The playbook copies a new start-up configuration to CISCO_ROUTER_01
choices.C: The playbook backs up the running configuration of CISCO_ROUTER_01
choices.B: The playbook copies a new running configuration to CISCO_ROUTER_01

discussion.content: Should be C
It is definitely C because "show running-config" shows the running and not the start-up config

Selected Answer: C
The output of show run is backed up on a file

Selected Answer: C
It sends a show run - not a show start. So C it is

Selected Answer: C
its clearly C, the command is "show running-config", "show conf" is the leaf name

show conf = Contents of Non-Volatile memory
show start-config = Contents of startup configuration
Show running = Current operating configuration
"Sh config" will return start-up config and "show running-config" will return the current running-config", here the command used is "show run" so the correct answer is C

comments.content: It's actually correct, it shows the startup-config. So the answer should be C.

discussion.content: no such command as sh conf
How come the answer is D? it is already on the script "Show running-config". C is the correct answer.

comments.content: where did you get the command "show conf"
'show config' is the task name. the command is 'show run'

Its difference from show run and show conf. 
show run = show running-config
show conf = show startup-config

D is correct.

discussion.content:
No doubt about C.
Assuming port 0/5 has native vlan (vlan 1), A is also correct. ( port 0/1 can pass vlan 1,6,7,8)
D is not correct, you need a router on stick topology for that.

A+C.

comments.content:
A+C are correct. I saw this question somewhere else and there are two blocks missing from the question (which show why A is correct), one of which puts Gi0/5 on VLAN 8. The missing blocks are below:

- ios_vlan:
 vlan_id: 7
 name corporate-vlan
 interfaces:
 - GigabitEthernet0/4

- ios_vlan:
 vlan_id: 8
 name: iot_vlan
 interfaces:
 - GigabitEthernet0/5
Thanks for adding the other blocks.

discussion.content: A & C are the right answers

B and E are obviously incorrect
C is obviously correct
that leaves:
A. Traffic from ports 0/2 to 0/5 is able to flow on port 0/1 due to the trunk
D. Traffic is able to flow between ports 0/2 to 0/5 due to the trunk on port 0/1

port 0/2 is in VLAN 6, port 0/5 is in VLAN 8 and port 0/1 is a trunk
From my perspective both A and D infer that inter-vlan routing exists somewhere that is accessible via the trunk on port 0/1. If this is the case, we can assume that routing exists both ways, so not just from 0/2 to 0/5 but the reverse as well, which would make it D for me

Selected Answer: AC
A and C
But I think the image is incomplete
A & C are correct. The trunk link allows multiple VLANS to traverse it. The access ports define which VLAN is tagged by that port when a packet/frame enters the switchport.

comments.content: I don’t see Gi0/5 on the Ansible snippet

discussion.content:
A & C is the correct answer.

Gi0/1 - trunk, can pass vlans(6,7,8)
Gi0/2 & Gi0/3 - access, vlan 6
Gi0/4 - access, vlan 7
Gi0/5 - access, vlan8

B is wrong since Gi 0/1 is configured as trunk port
D is wrong because traffic can not pass between Gi0/2 and Gi0/5 since they are on different vlans
E Gi0/6 is not stated

comments.content: it says "between". Trunk allow that those VLAN traffic pass through it BUT a TRUNK DONT combine them. You need Inter-vlan to do that and there is no mention about inter vlan configuration besides, only a L3 device can do it like a Router or L3 switch, and a Switch 2960CX is only a L2 device, without L3 functionality.

discussion.content: Why D is incorrect? A and D seems be same meaning.

The image is missing the following after vlan 7 config:
- ios_vlan:
 vlan_id: 8
 name: iot-vlan
 interfaces:
 GigabitEthernet0/5

Anyway, A & C are the correct answers.

B is not true since it was configured as a trunk port pruned with VLANs 6-8.

D is not true. Segregation is what VLANs are for.

E is obviously not true. There’s no port 0/6 in the script.

I thik is A and D are correct. C is not correct because the "access" command is missing in the configuration.
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/modules/ios_l2_interfaces_module.html

It's A and C.
port 0/2 and 0/3 are part of VLAN 6 (switch port access vlan 6)
port 0/4 is part of VLAN 7 ( switch port access vlan 7 ) (answer C)
on port 0/1, we are tagging VLAN 6 - 8, hence traffic from port 0/2 - 0/4 can flow through port 01

C and D
port 2 and 3 are access port. So that traffic should be available on the trunk port from outside.
we cant discus with gig 5, its is not mentioned in the Ansible play

comments.content: You don't need Trunk port to access port that are in the same VLAN (D) suggest that the two access port will need the trunk to communicate making it a wrong choice
D. should be a wrong answer. The trunk port will carry the VLANS but it is still unknown whether there would be routing for different broadcast domains. A and C should be the correct answer.

discussion.content: I think A has sense, but D has more sense since is both way

choices.C: GigabitEthernet0/2 and GigabitEthernet0/3 are access ports for VLAN 6.
choices.A: Traffic from ports 0/2 to 0/5 is able to flow on port 0/1 due to the trunk.
choices.D: Traffic is able to flow between ports 0/2 to 0/5 due to the trunk on port 0/1.
choices.E: Traffic on ports 0/2 and 0/3 is connected to port 0/6.

choices.D: creates a new branch called ג€my-projectג€
choices.B: initiates a new Git repository called ג€my-projectג€
choices.C: creates a copy of a branch called ג€my-projectג€
choices.A: creates a local copy of a repository called ג€my-projectג€

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
clone command is used for cloning.
Very obvious

without special chars:
What is the outcome of executing this command?
git clone ssh:/john@example.com/path/to/my-project.git
A. creates a local copy of a repository called “my-project”
B. initiates a new Git repository called “my-project”
C. creates a copy of a branch called “my-project”
D. creates a new branch called “my-project”

Selected Answer: A
A is correct:
git clone is primarily used to point to an existing repo and make a clone or copy of that repo at in a new directory, at another location. The original repository can be located on the local filesystem or on remote machine accessible supported protocols. The git clone command copies an existing Git repository.
A is the correct answer.

choices.D: A new start-up configuration is copied to the IOS router.
choices.C: The current running configuration of the IOS router is backed up.
